4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time

Task Production Performance Thought Process

• What are the monthly install targets?

• How much can one team member deliver?

• How much should each team deliver?

• Expected vs Target vs Optimized Production?

• Can the current team size deliver? Do we need to hire? When?

• Efficiency Opportunities?

• Will this drive speed and volume?

• Will the teams be excited about this program?

• Jobs are more than task production.  Can we ensure we don’t miss key day to day activities?

• How can we increase efficiency?
• Increase Production w/ same or Limited Headcount Growth in 40ish hour week

• What Pays for the Bonus?
• Inside Sales Framework: Live Last 18 Months

• 3 Salaries Delivers Production of 6 Salaries

content.title: Annual Planning and the Future.pdf

parts: Please remember to search the user's documents if an answer to their question is not contained in the above snippets.

The document you provided gives a comprehensive look at Lumina Solar's business strategy, internal culture, operational goals, and growth plans, particularly focusing on a four-year span from 2021 to 2024. Here’s a deep dive analysis based on key takeaways from the PDF:

### 1. **Mission and Core Values**:
   - **Mission**: Lumina Solar's mission is to scale the transition to a renewable-based economy in the mid-Atlantic region by deploying residential and commercial solar, maintaining energy infrastructure, offering solar storage, and providing EV chargers.
   - **Core Cultural Aspirations**: Lumina emphasizes a high-performance culture while maintaining a great workplace environment. Core cultural values include innovation, customer accountability, treating people well, consistency, transparency, and problem-solving frameworks【5†source】.

### 2. **Growth Strategy**:
   - **Four-Year Plan (2021-2024)**: The plan targets sustainable growth by expanding residential and commercial solar services and energy services (such as EV charging). Each year builds on the previous year’s achievements, focusing on growing market share and refining operational efficiency【5†source】.
   - **Residential Focus**: By 2024, Lumina aims to solidify its position as a top player in the residential solar market in Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Virginia【5†source】.
   - **Commercial Focus**: A strong emphasis is placed on developing the commercial solar sector to become a significant profit driver and expanding the company’s reach in this space【5†source】【5†source】.

### 3. **Operational Efficiency**:
   - Lumina's long-term goals include streamlining operations and increasing profitability through internal process improvements. This includes adjustments to compensation structures to incentivize performance and productivity【5†source】.
   - **Speed and Focus**: A major strategic advantage for Lumina is its focus on speed and adaptability. The company emphasizes the importance of quick decision-making and operational agility to stay ahead of competitors, while maintaining a culture of transparency and accountability【5†source】.

### 4. **People and Culture**:
   - Lumina's culture is built around **high-performance standards**. They prioritize nurturing talent through deep training, raising the talent bar, and hiring slowly but firing quickly when necessary to maintain performance levels. This contributes to the company’s goal of attracting top-end talent and fostering a culture of accountability【5†source】.
   - **Transparency**: Lumina hosts monthly town halls to openly discuss key performance indicators (KPIs), company challenges, and individual successes. The company believes transparency builds trust and speeds up decision-making【5†source】.

### 5. **Innovation and Competitive Differentiation**:
   - Lumina aims to drive constant innovation in product offerings, services, and internal processes to stay ahead of industry trends, asking critical questions like, "How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?" The company seeks to differentiate itself through not just what they offer but **how** they offer it, emphasizing deep customer relationships, financial strength, and strong internal training【5†source】.

### 6. **Compensation and Talent Management**:
   - The company's new compensation strategy is designed to align individual performance with company profitability, offering objective performance-based bonuses across different teams (residential, commercial, and support teams). The goal is to create a win-win-win scenario where high performance drives company growth, profitability, and personal financial rewards【5†source】.
   - **High Talent Density**: The company aspires to increase its talent density, particularly at the senior leadership level, as a key driver of future success【5†source】.

### 7. **Future Plans and Forecasts**:
   - Lumina's **2024 forecast** aims for continued market expansion and further growth in key areas such as residential dominance in Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Virginia, and commercial leadership in the solar space. Their 10-year plan reflects an ambition to lead in both residential and commercial sectors while scaling energy services【5†source】.

### 8. **Challenges and Adaptation**:
   - Lumina Solar highlights its past challenges, particularly in managing labor issues and profitability between 2018-2021. However, the company has positioned itself for future success by focusing on profitability, talent density, and operational excellence【5†source】.
   - **2024 Projections**: The company projects a revenue range of $69-$95M for 2024, with specific goals of reducing costs of goods sold (COGS), growing margins, and becoming a self-sustaining commercial business【5†source】.

### 9. **Leadership Development**:
   - Leadership development and growth planning are central to Lumina's future success, with a strong emphasis on hiring and nurturing top talent at all levels, from individual contributors to senior leadership. A priority is placed on building leaders who align with the company's core mission and can drive both cultural and financial success【5†source】.

### Conclusion:
Lumina Solar is heavily focused on growth, both in terms of market share and internal operations. The company’s commitment to innovation, transparency, talent development, and customer-centric operations positions it as a dynamic player in the solar industry. With ambitious goals for 2024 and beyond, Lumina is preparing to capitalize on market opportunities while mitigating risks through disciplined management and operational excellence.

This strategic overview outlines the company's evolution, challenges, and forward-thinking approach to leadership, innovation, and sustainable growth.

PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

Build Hidden Differentiators

harder for competition to replicate.

design software, anything in our proposal

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?

– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.

you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours

PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?



4 Year Plan

• 2024 Targets

• 10 Year Plan

metadata.text:
PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram.

9Decision Making: Spending Money

• Context Context Context

• Horrible decision, ridiculously expensive, requires policy control updates

• Smart Financial Decisions Can Be:
• Spending (Investing) Money

• Not Spending Money

• Spending Decisions = Easy when Financials + Business Context Understood

PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?



4 Year Plan

• High Level Objectives

• 2024 Targets

• 10 Year Plan

Task Production Performance Thought Process

• What are the monthly install targets?

• How much can one team member deliver?

• How much should each team deliver?

• Expected vs Target vs Optimized Production?

• Can the current team size deliver? Do we need to hire? When?

• Efficiency Opportunities?

• Will this drive speed and volume?

• Will the teams be excited about this program?

• Jobs are more than task production.  Can we ensure we don’t miss key day to day activities?

• How can we increase efficiency?
• Increase Production w/ same or Limited Headcount Growth in 40ish hour week

metadata.text:
PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency

build the shipyard

families on site to move
