metadata.text:
PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?



4 Year Plan

• Historical

• High Level Objectives

• 2024 Targets

• 10 Year Plan

Core Mission

5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

place to work & grow.

21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram.

metadata.text:
PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?



4 Year Plan

• Historical

• High Level Objectives

• 2024 Targets

• 10 Year Plan

The 4 Year Plan

4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?

metadata.text:
PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?



4 Year Plan

• Historical

• High Level Objectives

• 2024 Targets

• 10 Year Plan

PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but 
you’re 2 meetings/40 hours behind.

• You decide when to apply

• Applicable when presenting ideas to a team or 
cancelling a meeting
– Requires quality notes

• Trust team to digest. Hold accountable to content 
knowledge.
– 30 minutes of thoughtful bullet points can save your team 

10 hours 

– 20X Return on your team’s time



34Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What Cultural Changes Do You Want to Make?

• Hard, but not impossible

• Toussaint L’Ouverture: led only successful slave 
revolution in history → Haiti, 1791

• Shaka Senghor: murder convict transformed 
large, violent prison gang

• Perspective



Questions, comments, concerns?

Future deep dive any retreat topics?

Is this how you want to build a 

company?



4 Year Plan

• High Level Objectives

• 2024 Targets

• 10 Year Plan

metadata.text:
PowerPoint Presentation


DO NOT DISTRIBUTE. INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS DOCUMENT IS CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY
1

Annual Planning Slides



2

2021



The 4 Year Plan

• Mission

• Building our Culture

• Historical Milestones

• Annual Overview ‘21-’24

• 10 Year Plan



4Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core Mission

• Core Mission: Scale the transition to a 

renewable based economy in the mid-

Atlantic

– Deploying residential + commercial solar 

– Maintaining energy infrastructure via 

maintenance

– Solar storage

– EV Chargers



5Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

The Team we build is the Company we build.

Everything else is of secondary importance.

Why?



6Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Core People Mission

“In good organizations, people can focus on their 
work and have confidence that if they get their work 
done, good things will happen for both the company 
and them personally.  

Every person can wake up knowing that the work 
they do will be efficient, effective, and make a 
difference for the organization and themselves. 
These things make their jobs both motivating and 
fulfilling.” 

-Ben Horowitz



7Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

What is Culture?

• The collective behavior of individuals within an 

organization → the standards that are 

practiced.

– A company with a great culture & poor product will 

fail.

– A great product offering & terrible culture will fail 

over time.

– Great Culture + Good Foundation = Lasting Impact



8Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Culture

• Lumina’s Business Foundation is Strong

• Our culture is good, but rarely discussed

• How Created:

– Design

– Accident

– Mistakes

• Cultural nuance across teams & departments

– Company culture vs install culture vs sales culture vs engineering 
culture vs operations culture etc



9Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Lumina’s Cultural Design Objective

Building a high-performance culture while being a great 

place to work & grow.

Forever building the idealized version of Lumina Solar.



10Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Cultural Components & Aspirations

• High Performance-Standards

• Treat People Well

• Innovation

• Consistency

• Customer Accountability, Customer Experience

• Problem Solving Framework

• Hyper Focused

• Speed

• Decision Making

• Transparency

• Build Hidden Differentiators

• Company Meetings

• Compete over Time



11Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High-Performance Standards

• Does your team know their objectives?

• Do you hold them accountable? How?

• Where is your work quality floor?  This is the standard.

• Hire slow, fire fast
– Talent > Bodies

• Nurture talent
– Deep training, high talent bar already in place, top performers 

attract top performers

– Increase organization’s talent density

• 2 Year Window
– Long-term success inevitable 

• Customer experience, company reputation, and high talent 
bar attracts more customers & top end talent
– Snowball effect



12Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Treat People Well

• Paid well, appreciated, recognized
– Raises are annual or via promotion

• Don’t be a jerk

• Involved in decisions
– Push downstream to improve speed and quality

• Context necessary & providing it → company focus
– “That’s your decision” more over time

• Deploying $100M construction projects in 12 months
– Core growth & development

– Requires 50-100 people with high end talent & leadership skills

• Preference to promote internally over external hire, but not always possible.

• Turn Over 

• Employee new hire referrals have been outstanding
– Only refer top talent

– No one wants to bring on a low performer

– Not a charity

– Ownership over company success



13Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Innovation

• Product offerings, services, process 

efficiency, distribution & operations model

– How will companies sell and install solar in 2025?

• Improvements on the margins add up

• Drive improvements but react quickly when 

necessary



14Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Consistency

• I want people to be able to predict what decision I will 
make as often as possible in a given situation
– Flow downstream

• Starts with routine decisions, complexity increases 
over time as team grows their knowledge, skills, and 
context

• Consistency = reliability

• Can the team rely on their leaders?  Can leaders rely 
on their team?
– Consistency builds this trust

• More trust = less friction = greater organizational 
efficiency
– Trust = Consistency + Time



15Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Customer Accountability

Customer Experience

• We drill customer experience into our 

culture

– No evidence of other orgs tracking reviews

– Forefront of Lumina by design

• We go above and beyond to fix issues 

and are transparent with our customers.

– Our reputation > $2k mistake



16Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving Framework

• What is the fastest, most efficient solution? Then 

execute.

– Post-resolution, deep dive root cause for prevention

• We tolerate mistakes

– Limited tolerance for making the same mistake twice.

– Concept situationally dependent based on complexity 

• This does NOT mean we don’t take risks.  

– We cannot tolerate repeated dumb or lazy mistakes 

• The Martian: Calm during Crisis 



17Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Problem Solving



18Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hyper Focus

• Deep Focus + Innovative Culture leaves good ideas on the 
sidelines for years
– We can’t do it all.  We’re transparent about this with context.

– We choose the things we are great at.  We choose the things we 
suck at.

• Get better @ saying “No”
– Save your time & company resources 

– Recognizing great opportunities vs time sucks is HARD
• Storage, Tesla Roof example

• Killing bad processes and project types

• Understanding internal skills & bandwidth
– We can’t do everything all at once

• Choose 1 initiative @ 85% quality or 2 @ 40% quality? Depends…

– Set improvement targets annually, adjust quarterly (or monthly)



19Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Speed

• Fast improvements (target list every quarter)

• Fast adaptability (when appropriate, react and adjust quickly to 
market forces)

• Operations

• Big companies are slow.  Small companies suck.
– Speed = incredible advantage in nearly any competitive environment

• Maintain advantage for as long as possible

• Keep in culture as we grow
– Pushing decisions down stream is scary but critical

– What decisions do you unnecessarily require approval for?
• Start w/ low risk decisions, increase complexity over time

• Goal: Accomplish 2 years’ worth of work every 12 months
– Hyper Focus + Speed Combo 

• NOT 80 HOUR WORK WEEKS



20Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

The Alaska Highway. Starting in 1942, 1,700 miles of 

military roadway were built over the course of 234 days, 

connecting eastern British Columbia with Fairbanks, 

Alaska. 



21Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Wartime Speed

Marinship. Shipyard construction was begun promptly after a 
telegram from the United States Maritime Commission was 
received by the W. A. Bechtel Company. 

• The telegram was received on March 2, 1942

• Site selected on March 3rd

• Proposal presented on March 9th

• 10 minutes into the presentation, administrators approved to 
build the shipyard

• Shipyard construction delayed two weeks to allow the 42 
families on site to move 

• Construction began on March 28th

• First ship completed September 15th of that year, 197 days 
after receiving the telegram. 



22Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

• Disneyland. Walt Disney's conception of "The Happiest 

Place on Earth" was brought to life in 366 days. 



23Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

More Speed

The Empire State Building. Construction was started and 
finished in 410 days. 

https://patrickcollison.com/fast

https://patrickcollison.com/fast


24Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making

• Speed 

– Push more downstream

• Quality

– Teach more context, learn more context

• Experience Advantage

– Cross functional solar context

– Minimize extended cross departmental debates w/ 
enhanced context & transparency among 
employees

• SpaceX Example

• Lumina Examples



25Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Decision Making Context

• Spring Example: Customer Care Concerns 

with Sales Team

– No formal Customer Care Team in place

– 30-minute discussion on thought process building 

out customer care the last 2 years and our long-

term approach

• Challenge: failure to deliver = breach of trust



26Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Hard Leadership

• Strong opinions, weakly held

• Disagree & commit



27Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Monthly Town Hall
– Review KPIs across functions, celebrate individual successes, 

relay company challenges and improvements in process or on 
the horizon

– No cancels…consistency

• Annual Report published to all employees

• Openly discuss our successes/shortcomings
– Fix problems quick when appropriate

– Duct tape problems when they can’t be fixed in the short term 
and explain why

• Extensive Company Orientation

• Transparency is Hard, Belief in Benefits 



28Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Transparency

• Heavily transparent culture minus financial KPIs 

– Reason: Too hard/annoying to explain financial context regularly to 
entire employee base

– No context = no meaning or poor interpretations

– Overview today

• High Transparency 

– Speeds individual growth

– Provides decision making context

– More enjoyable work environment

– More effective @ driving progress



29Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Build Hidden Differentiators

• Why? Strengthens our company moat, 
harder for competition to replicate.

– Easy for competition to replicate:
• Reduce pricing, residential product offering, aurora 

design software, anything in our proposal

– Difficult for competition to replicate:
• How we utilize Aurora, deep commercial 

relationships, high end training, retention, financial 
strength & resulting decisions, HOW we drive 
reviews…

– What can you build or grow?



30Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Meeting Culture

• Meetings = useful tool to circulate information and 
debate decisions
– They can also be time killers

• Meeting lite organization
– How much value are we getting out of this meeting?

– A weekly 10-person meeting = 520-man hours annually
• Are we getting at least $26k+ in value?

• What if we cut meeting cadence in half?  

• What could we accomplish with the additional 260 hours?

• Is this meeting being run with Ruthless Efficiency?
– 1 v 1s are very different in this context

• Retreat: $20k in time (272 hours) & spend
– Expectation of $1M+ ROI next 18 months

• 2% efficiency increase on $60M+



31Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

High Quality Meetings

• Non-weekly high level information pipeline on important 
issues

– Internal rapport builder

• Training and professional growth

• Sensitive topics

• Decision debates with context/summary out prior to 
discussion

• Effective 1 v 1s



32Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Poor Quality Meetings

• Topic introduction meetings suck: use 

email instead 

• Reviewing regular data that is widely 

available: use email or dashboards

• Meetings for the sake of meetings

• Is the meeting useful or habitual?



33Confidential and Proprietary—Do Not Distribute

Pre-Meeting Preparation

• On one hand, send out the notes before a meeting
– Less exciting, higher-level discussion.  

• Or present something new and more exciting, but
